turns.speaker: LIME
turns.text: Sod it, it's broken!

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: You haven't switched it on.

turns.speaker: LIME
turns.text: Oh - yes. Look you're putting me off, standing there! Go back to your office and I'll give you a knock when I've finished.

turns.speaker: LIME
turns.text: Hey - that's my desk!

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Gillian Layton - Suspect S/5173. Truck driver! All enquiries, reference officer 412/L - Room 5001.  That's what I wanted to know. Thank you very much.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Lime, I need to use your computer

turns.speaker: LIME
turns.text: Sorry, a bit busy at the moment.  You seem to have quite a lot to do yourself.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: My mother said it would be all right.

turns.speaker: MATTHEWS
turns.text: She didn't say anything about it to me.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Well, she's my mother, not yours.

turns.speaker: MATTHEWS
turns.text: I won't be held responsible.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: How long will she he away?

turns.speaker: MATTHEWS
turns.text: There are some who go to Dr. Jaffe's clinic who never come back at all.

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: Hello, Spiro. Merry Christmas.

turns.speaker: SPIRO
turns.text: I'm sorry but ...

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: You remember Samuel, my son.

turns.speaker: SPIRO
turns.text: {suddenly unctious) Oh, but of course ...

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: We're meeting Mrs Terrain.

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: Oh, to hell with the diet, a number eight, please.

turns.speaker: SPIRO
turns.text: A most perceptive choice, Madam, if I may say so.  Monsieur?

turns.speaker: SPIRO
turns.text: Numero une, crevettes Ã  la mayonaaise.

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: I'm sorry Alma, I didn't mean to sound so ...

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: I just wish you would stop interfering, mother! I don't want promotion. I'm happy where I am.

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: No you're not. Jack Lint is a lesson to you - he never had your brains but he's got the ambition. You haven't got the ambition but luckily you've got me. And Mr Helpmann. Mr Helpmann was very close -

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: Mr Helpmann was very close to your poor father. He was very close to me. Still is. He'll take you under his wing at Information Retrieval. You'll like it when you get there.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: You're not listening, mother.

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: I hope you like it. It's very exclusive.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: What is it?

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: It's something for executives.

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: What were we saying?

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: This isn't rare!

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: By the way, I saw a wonderful idea for Christmas presents at the chemists. Gift tokens. Medical gift tokens.

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: Actually, Alma, that's one of the little things I was dying to tell you ... Sam's been promoted to Information Retrieval.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Mother!

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: Sam ... you haven't had dessert.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: I'm sorry. I don' t want dessert. I don't want promotion. I don't want anything.

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: Don't be childish, Samuel. Of course you want something. You must have hopes, wishes, dreams.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Mother? Is that you?

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: Of course. Isn't it wonderful? The bandages came of this afternoon. Come and join the fun. Everybody's here.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Is Mr Helpmann here?

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: Yes he is - he wants to talk to you.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: I want to talk to him.

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: It seems you're the first person ever to turn down a promotion. He thinks you should see a doctor.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Actually, I've decided ...

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: Sam!!!

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Mother? ... What ... what's ... you've got to help me ...

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: Not now ... please

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: It's a refund ... I'm afraid there was a mistake.

turns.speaker: MRS BUTTLE
turns.text: Mistake?

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Yes. Not my department ... I'm only records. It seems that Mr Buttle was overcharged by Information Retrieval. I don't think they usually make mistakes ... but, er ... I suppose we're all human.

turns.speaker: MRS BUTTLE
turns.text: My husband's dead, isn't he?

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Er ... I assure you Mrs Buttle, the Ministry is always very scrupulous about following up and eradicating error. If you have any complaints which you'd like to make, I'd be more than happy to send you the appropriate forms.

turns.speaker: MRS BUTTLE
turns.text: What have you done with his body?

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Um ...

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Uh ...

turns.speaker: MRS BUTTLE
turns.text: He hadn't done anything ... He was good ... What have you done with his body?

turns.speaker: MRS TERRAIN
turns.text: Really, Sam - when are you going to do something about these terrorists?

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: What? Now? It's my lunch hour.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Whatever happened to you?

turns.speaker: MRS TERRAIN
turns.text: There was a slight complication. Dr. Chapman says it often happens with a delicate skin like mine. Nothing to worry about. He's promised me I'll have these bandages off in a ...

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Actually, there's someone I want to meet ...

turns.speaker: MRS TERRAIN
turns.text: I know, I know ...!

turns.speaker: MRS TERRAIN
turns.text: Here we are! I'm going to leave you two lovebirds in peace.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Ah ... hello, Mrs Terrain. SAM lets go of the parcel and pushes JILL away. She moves off.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: I think that'll hold it.  Hello Shirley. Just helping someone tie up a Christmas present. How are you?

turns.speaker: MRS TERRAIN
turns.text: My complication had a complication, but Dr Chapman says I'll soon be up and bouncing about like a young gazelle. Are you buying a Christmas present for your mother?

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Er, yes ...

turns.speaker: MRS TERRAIN
turns.text: Shirley and I come here regularly. I love romantic lingerie.

turns.speaker: MRS TERRAIN
turns.text: I can't make up my mind whether to have a number one or a number two. What do you recommend, Spiro?

turns.speaker: SPIRO
turns.text: Between you and me, Madam, today the number two.

turns.speaker: MRS TERRAIN
turns.text: Thank you, Spiro. Shirley, what are you going to have?

turns.speaker: SPIRO
turns.text: Numero huit, braised veal in wine sauce.

turns.speaker: MRS TERRAIN
turns.text: It's too exciting. I've left Dr Jaffe and gone to Dr. Chapman.

turns.speaker: SPIRO
turns.text: Numero deux, duck a l'orange.

turns.speaker: MRS TERRAIN
turns.text: That's all right Ida ... it's just that he's such an artist. To him, cutting is so crude ... so primitive.

turns.speaker: SPIRO
turns.text: Numero trois, steak.  Monsieur, Mesdames, Bon appetit.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Hello - Central Services - I'm at 579B Block l9, Northwestern Section D - that's exit 1 on Green Pastures Highway at the Orange Blossom Flyover - and I've got trouble with the air- conditioning

turns.speaker: PHONE VOICE
turns.text: Thank you or calling Central Services. am sorry, due to temporary staff shortage, Central Services cannot take service calls centrally between 2300 and 0900 hours - have a nice day - this has not been a recording, incident-

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: This is an emergency!

turns.speaker: PHONE VOICE
turns.text: Thank you for calling Central Services. I am sorry, due -

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Yes, but. I've got to have a heating engineer

turns.speaker: PHONE VOICE
turns.text: Thank you for calling Cen -

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Hello ... hello ...

turns.speaker: PHONE VOICE
turns.text: Hello. Mr Lowry?

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Who's that?

turns.speaker: PHONE VOICE
turns.text: Put the phone down and your hands up.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: What? Who is this?

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: My name is Sam Lowry. I have to report to Mr Warren.

turns.speaker: PORTER
turns.text: Thirtieth floor, sir. You're expected.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Er, don't you want to search me?

turns.speaker: PORTER
turns.text: No, sir.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: My I.D. cards.

turns.speaker: PORTER
turns.text: No need, sir

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: But I could be anybody.

turns.speaker: PORTER
turns.text: No you couldn't, sir. This is Information Retrieval.  the lift's arrived, sir.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Excuse me, Dawson, can you put me through to Mr Helpmann's office?

turns.speaker: PORTER
turns.text: I'm afraid I can't, sir. You have to go through the proper channels.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: And you can't tell me what the proper channels are, because that's classified information?

turns.speaker: PORTER
turns.text: I'm glad to see the Ministry's continuing its tradition of recruiting the brightest and best, sir.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Thank you, Dawson.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Are we?

turns.speaker: SPIRO
turns.text: Ah yes, the lady is waiting.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: A steak, please. Rare.  Mother, I need to ...

turns.speaker: SPIRO
turns.text: Monsieur. Quel numero.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: I don't know which numero.

turns.speaker: SPIRO
turns.text: Numero, trois.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: what? ... Oh ...

turns.speaker: SPIRO
turns.text: Madam ... CUT to WOMAN turning, half in flirtatious conversation. It is SAM's MOTHER, but miraculously another twenty years younger and ... a parody of SAM's Dream Girl.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Yes?

turns.speaker: SPOOR
turns.text: Central Services.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: No, not at all. I mean, it's all right. It's fixed.

turns.speaker: SPOOR
turns.text: Fixed?

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: I mean it fixed itself.

turns.speaker: SPOOR
turns.text: Fixed itself.

turns.speaker: SPOOR
turns.text: Now look what you've done to him.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Have you got one or haven't you?

turns.speaker: SPOOR
turns.text: Not ... as such ...

turns.speaker: SPOOR
turns.text: But we can get one.

turns.speaker: SPOOR
turns.text: It's all right, Terry, it's all right, everything's all right.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: I'm sorry, but I'm a bit of a stickler for paper work. Where would we be if we didn't follow the correct procedures?

turns.speaker: SPOOR
turns.text: We'll be back.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: What the - ? How did you - ?

turns.speaker: SPOOR
turns.text: Emergency procedures.

turns.speaker: SPOOR
turns.text: Sign here please.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: What is it?

turns.speaker: SPOOR
turns.text: It's a 27B/6, what did you think it was?

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: SPOOR
turns.text: Who fixed your ducts?

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Hang on! Wait a minute! You can't just go and leave it like this!

turns.speaker: SPOOR
turns.text: Why not? All you've got to do is blow yer nose and fix it, haven't you?

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: For God's sake, what's happened?

turns.speaker: SPOOR
turns.text: Thermostat's gone. And then some.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: What is it?

turns.speaker: SPOOR
turns.text: It's a 27B/6 of course.

turns.speaker: TUTTLE
turns.text: Nice and easy now. Keep your hands where I can see them.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: What is this?  Who the hell are you?

turns.speaker: TUTTLE
turns.text: Harry Tuttle. Heating engineer. At your service.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Tuttle! Are you from Central Services?

turns.speaker: TUTTLE
turns.text: Ha!!

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: But ... I called Central Services.

turns.speaker: TUTTLE
turns.text: They're a bit overworked these days. Luckily I intercepted your call.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: TUTTLE
turns.text: A little precaution, sir. I've had traps set for me before now. There are people in Central Services who'd love to get their hands on Harry Tuttle.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Are you saying this is illegal?

turns.speaker: TUTTLE
turns.text: Well, yes ... and no. Officially, only Central Service operatives are supposed to touch this stuff ... Could you hold these.

turns.speaker: TUTTLE
turns.text: ... but, with all the new rules and regulations ... unncgh, c'mon, c'mon ... they can't get decent staff any more ... so ... they tend to turn a blind eye ... as long as I'm careful.  ... Mind you, if ever they could prove I'd been working on their equipment ... well, that's a different matter ... up a bit with the torch, sir.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Sorry. wouldn't it be easier just to work for Central Services?

turns.speaker: TUTTLE
turns.text: Couldn't stand the pa - ah - we're getting warm -

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: The pace?

turns.speaker: TUTTLE
turns.text: The paperwork, couldn't stand the paperwork.  Over to the left please, if you don't mind sir. Hold it there. Yes, there's more bits of paper in Central Services than bits of pipe - read this, fill in that, hand in the other - listen, this old system of yours could be on fire and I couldn't even turn on the kitchen tap without filling in a 27B/6.... Bloody paperwork.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Well I suppose one has to expect a certain amount

turns.speaker: TUTTLE
turns.text: Why? I came into this game for adventure - go anywhere, travel light, get in, get out, wherever there's trouble, a man alone. Now they've got the whole country sectioned of and you can't move without a form. I'm the last of a breed. Ah ha! Found it!  There's your problem.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Can you fix it?

turns.speaker: TUTTLE
turns.text: No. But I can bypass it with one of these

turns.speaker: TUTTLE
turns.text: Are you expecting anyone?

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: No. Wait here.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Listen .. um ... I don't want to get involved in any of this. But I work at the Ministry of Information, and I happen to know that Information Retrieval have been looking for an Archibald Tuttle, Heating Engineer. You wouldn't by any chance be -

turns.speaker: TUTTLE
turns.text: My friends call me Harry. Information Retrieval, eh? Interesting!

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: What do they want you or?

turns.speaker: TUTTLE
turns.text: Time to go.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Thank you very much. How much will it...?

turns.speaker: TUTTLE
turns.text: On the house. You did me a favor. Check the corridor.

turns.speaker: CAPT. BARNEY
turns.text: What am I going to to do with this guy?  Pierce, I was just on the phone with Borough Command. Out of twelve shifts this month, you've been late for nine, sick four and that includes the shift where you came late and went home early.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: I'm sick. That's what I've been telling you.

turns.speaker: CAPT. BARNEY
turns.text: You're killing me, you know that? You got no sick time according to Command. I've been told to terminate.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: It's okay. I'll just get my things out of the locker.

turns.speaker: CAPT. BARNEY
turns.text: I've never fired anyone in my life.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: I'm sorry Captain. Don't take it too hard.

turns.speaker: CAPT. BARNEY
turns.text: Nobody tells me to fire anyone. I told them: shove it up the big one.  Sorry.  I said, you want to fire him, come over and do it yourself.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: You know they won't do it. It's up to you. You gotta be strong.

turns.speaker: CAPT. BARNEY
turns.text: I feel for you, but we got an emergency here. It's a weekend of full moons.  Everyone's called in sick. Larry, Veeber, Stanley too. We need bodies out there. I had to put Marcus on Twelve Young. You know he's not supposed to work two nights in a row.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: You swore you'd fire me if I came in late again.

turns.speaker: CAPT. BARNEY
turns.text: I'll fire you tomorrow. Hell, better than that, I'll forward you some sick time. A week, two weeks off-- how about that?

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: I don't think a week's gonna do it.

turns.speaker: CAPT. BARNEY
turns.text: I'm sorry, Pierce.  You're going out with Marcus. Duty calls. The City needs you.

turns.speaker: CAPT. BARNEY
turns.text: You're late, Pierce. I know, but I can't fire you. I've got nobody to work sixteen XRay with Walls.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: No ...

turns.speaker: CAPT. BARNEY
turns.text: I got some forms here to fill out about that accident when you get the time.  I'll fire you tomorrow. I promise.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: What if there is no tomorrow?

turns.speaker: CAPT. BARNEY
turns.text: Go on, get outta here, Pierce, before I give you a big hug.  I love this guy.

turns.speaker: CARLOS
turns.text: No English. She has terrible pain in her belly.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Pregnant.

turns.speaker: CARLOS
turns.text: No, no, that's impossible.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Are you pregnant? Estas embarazada?

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Can you walk? Puedes caminar?

turns.speaker: CARLOS
turns.text: She say she in great pain.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Thanks for the translation.  What's your name? Nombre?

turns.speaker: CARLOS
turns.text: Is she dying?

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: She's having a baby. Twins.

turns.speaker: CARLOS
turns.text: Es impossible.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: You can trust me on this one.

turns.speaker: CARLOS
turns.text: It's a miracle.

turns.speaker: MARCUS
turns.text: You know each other a long time?

turns.speaker: CARLOS
turns.text: Two years. Ever since we left island.

turns.speaker: MARCUS
turns.text: In that time, you ever have sex?

turns.speaker: CARLOS
turns.text: Never. No cigarettes, no drugs, no booze.

turns.speaker: MARCUS
turns.text: No underwear?

turns.speaker: CARLOS
turns.text: We are virgins.

turns.speaker: KANITA
turns.text: Hey Cy, guess who's here?

turns.speaker: COATES
turns.text: Mary ...

turns.speaker: COATES
turns.text: It's okay, Kanita. Come on in.

turns.speaker: KANITA
turns.text: He looks like a cop.

turns.speaker: COATES
turns.text: He's not a cop, he's a medic.  I'm CY Coates.

turns.speaker: COATES
turns.text: Frank, take it easy. what happened?

turns.speaker: KANITA
turns.text: He flipped out.

turns.speaker: COATES
turns.text: Be cool, man. You're having a paradoxical reaction. It can happen.  Didn't I tell you this guy was stressed out?

turns.speaker: KANITA
turns.text: Stressed? He's psycho.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Frank Pierce.

turns.speaker: COATES
turns.text: Mary said you might be coming.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Where is she?

turns.speaker: COATES
turns.text: Sleeping in the back.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: She asked me to pick her up.

turns.speaker: COATES
turns.text: I know, but she told me to tell you she wants to crash here a few hours. Terrible about her father, isn't it?

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: I better just go in and see her.

turns.speaker: COATES
turns.text: She wanted something to help her sleep.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Mary, we really have to go.

turns.speaker: COATES
turns.text: I'm always interested in people in stressful occupations and being a paramedic is about as stressful as I can imagine. Here, sit down. What's it like? Tell me some war stories.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Got a beer?

turns.speaker: COATES
turns.text: That shit is poison, Frank. We don't drink alcohol here. What you need is one of these.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Did you give Mary something called Red Death?

turns.speaker: COATES
turns.text: Red Death?  Tell me something, Frank--does killing your clients make good business sense to you? The kids selling that shit have no sense. They'll be taken care of, don't worry about that.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: I should be going. I just quit.

turns.speaker: COATES
turns.text: Sleep is all stress reduction. Here.  You take one of these, sleep two hours, that's all you need.  Why do you think I'm telling you this, Frank--for my health?  You ought to look at yourself in the mirror, man. Kanita, get him a glass of water.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Is this what you gave Mary?

turns.speaker: COATES
turns.text: That's the stuff. I call it the Red Lion. Very king-of-the-jungle.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: I guess I'll be going.

turns.speaker: COATES
turns.text: Just take it easy.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Does that hurt?

turns.speaker: COATES
turns.text: No!

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: They're gonna torch the fence. You're gonna feel the metal getting warm, maybe very warm.

turns.speaker: COATES
turns.text: I can't hold up my head anymore.

turns.speaker: COATES
turns.text: So, Frank, am I going to live?

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: You're going to live.

turns.speaker: COATES
turns.text: I've been thinking about things. Meditating on my financial future. You guys gave me plenty of time to meditate on the future. Whatja do, stop for Chinese on the way over? There's plenty of food in my place.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: I was tired. I needed a coffee.

turns.speaker: COATES
turns.text: What about Kanita?

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Dead.

turns.speaker: COATES
turns.text: That's too bad. Get some money, a nice looking girl on your arm, and everyone wants to take a piece. Some kid I wouldn't let wash my Mercedes is in my house, shooting at me. Damn, I thought I could make it onto the balcony like Tiger. He's fat, that's why, falls faster. I'm trying to watch my weight, and look what happens. Am I shot, Frank?

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: COATES
turns.text: Boy can't shoot for shit, either. Goddamn that's hot.

turns.speaker: DISPATCHER LOVE
turns.text: Twelve Young, I don't have time for your games. Now answer me or do I have to come out there myself?

turns.speaker: MARCUS
turns.text: I usually don't do calls before coffee. But I think it might do you some good.  Twelve Young is here and I'm gonna take care of you, baby. Don't you worry about a thing, yahear, cause Marcus is alive and on arrival.

turns.speaker: DISPATCHER LOVE
turns.text: I'm not your baby, Young, I'm not your mother either. You're going to a cardiac arrest, Avenue C and Ninth, northeast corner. It's a club. Take the side entrance.

turns.speaker: MARCUS
turns.text: Ten-four, hon.  This is for you.

turns.speaker: DISPATCHER LOVE
turns.text: Twelve Young, answer the radio. I have a call for you.

turns.speaker: MARCUS
turns.text: She said to me, I love the way you talk on the radio.

turns.speaker: DISPATCHER LOVE
turns.text: I can't wait all night, Young. I'm holding a priority and if you don't answer I'm going to knock you out of service.

turns.speaker: MARCUS
turns.text: Don't worry, hon. Young is here and he's gonna help out--just remember, you owe me.

turns.speaker: DISPATCHER LOVE
turns.text: You're going to three-four Avenue C, 17 year-old female cardiac arrest, no further information.

turns.speaker: MARCUS
turns.text: Ten-four, hon.

turns.speaker: MARCUS
turns.text: Let's do it!  It's Marcus, Love, only for you.

turns.speaker: DISPATCHER LOVE
turns.text: Male diff breather, approximately 30, Houston and A.

turns.speaker: MARCUS
turns.text: Ten-four.

turns.speaker: MARCUS
turns.text: Okay, what happened?

turns.speaker: DRUMMER
turns.text: He's going to be all right, right?

turns.speaker: MARCUS
turns.text: No. He's dead.

turns.speaker: DRUMMER
turns.text: No way, man.

turns.speaker: MARCUS
turns.text: He's dead and there's nothing we can do. Come on, Frank, that's it.

turns.speaker: DRUMMER
turns.text: All right, all right, he's been snorting that Red Death stuff. Been going for four days.

turns.speaker: MARCUS
turns.text: What's his name?

turns.speaker: DRUMMER
turns.text: IB Bangin.

turns.speaker: MARCUS
turns.text: What'd you mean IB Bangin? What kind of name is IB Bangin?

turns.speaker: NOEL
turns.text: Excuse me. You are a very kind man. I can see that. A man like you could not refuse a poor sick dying helpless man a small cup of water.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: I can't. I have to stay with my patient.

turns.speaker: NOEL
turns.text: See, I can't do it. I came out of the desert.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: You came out of the hospital. You were tied down and hallucinating. You got some bad chemicals in your head, Noel. There's some medicine at the hospital that will fix that.

turns.speaker: NOEL
turns.text: No, no medicine!

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Noel, you didn't let me finish. We have rules against killing people on the street. Looks bad, but there's a special room at the hospital for terminating. A nice quiet room with a big bed.

turns.speaker: NOEL
turns.text: Oh man, do you mean that?  Thank you man, thank you. How?

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Well, you have your choice: pills, injection, gas.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: You're not going to die.

turns.speaker: NOEL
turns.text: What did you say?

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Shut up. You're going to die and he's not. Got it.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: That's a hell of a swing you got there, Noel. I'm thinking Strawberry in his prime.

turns.speaker: NOEL
turns.text: Strawberry ain't shit. Drug pussy.  Me.  I swing like Reggie. Mr. October. Number three, game six, World Series.

turns.speaker: NOEL
turns.text: Here, you try.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: No, I'd better not.

turns.speaker: NOEL
turns.text: Sure, sure, give go.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Yeah?

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: What the hell.  The next year, tiebreaker for the division, in Boston, Yanks down two to nothing, Bucky Dent steps to the plate.

turns.speaker: NOEL
turns.text: Oh man, Bucky.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: The pitch, high heater. Bucky knows what's coming. He steps in, smash, over the green monster.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Do you have any music?

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Music. I think it helps if you play something he liked.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: John, play the Sinatra.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Is he going to be alright?

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: His heart's beating.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: He's very very sick.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: I know him. That's Noel.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: We'd better go outside. Quickly.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Is there any chance?

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: I guess there's always a chance.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: I wouldn't do that.  The doctor seems to think he's suffering from some rare disorder.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: It's not so rare. He grew up on our street. He's had a rough life and he's a little crazy from it, but that's no excuse for not giving someone a lousy cup of water.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: It's my first cigarette in over a year.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: The first is always the best.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: It's the waiting that's killing me, not knowing, you know? It's really hard on my mother. The doctor doesn't think my father'll make it. He says he was dead too long, after six minutes the brain starts to die and once that goes, close the door.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: You never know.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: I mean if he was dead, I could handle that.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: At least he's got people around him.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: I'm not so sure. My father and I haven't spoken in three years. When my brother called to say my father was having a heart attack, that he'd locked himself in the bathroom, all the way going over I was thinking how I was gonna tell him what a bastard he was. Then when I got up the stairs and we moved him onto the bed, I thought of all these other things I wanted to say.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Even when you say the things, there's always more things.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Right now, I'm more worried about my mother than anything. They won't let her see my father.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Go home. Take her home. Get some rest. Not going to find anything out now.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: That's what I told her. If she could just see him a second, then I could take her home.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: You shouldn't smoke.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: It's okay. They're prescription.  Works better with a little whiskey.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: That's my brother's problem. He's passed out inside.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: That boy you brought in, he was shot, wasn't he?

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: He's dead, huh?

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: I think this place stinks.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Our Lady of Misery.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Did you see my father?

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: It's crazy in there. What's wrong with that doctor? He keeps mumbling, poking himself in the eye when he talks to me.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: He's working a double shift.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Thing is, I'm supposed to be the fuckup. The one on the stretcher in there--that's supposed to be me. With my parents crying out here. I got a lot of guilt, you know what I mean?

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: My father's in a coma, now my mother's going crazy. It's like she's in a trance.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: She should go home.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: I'd take her, but then who would stay here?

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Yes?

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Hello, I'm Frank Pierce, from the ambulance last night. I brought your father into the hospital and I just learned some news.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: I'll be right down.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: He's better, isn't he?

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Well, the doctor says he's showing some movement. It's still early, it might mean nothing, but I thought you'd want to know.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: I knew. I sensed it when I heard your voice.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: You look so different.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: I know. It's awful, isn't it? Night of the Living Cheerleaders.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: I think it looks good.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: I was going nuts in that waiting room so I came back to check on my mom.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: How is she?

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Sleeping.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: I was just going to get some food. Pizza. Maybe we could.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: You can't kill my father that easy. He'll fight forever. Like with me: hasn't talked to me in three years. But it's okay. Sometimes you have to put things behind you.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Be tough to get a taxi here. We can give you a ride if you like.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Okay.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: He wants to pull that tube out. It's pretty painful--that's why they keep him sedated--but it's a good sign.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: You sure? I know my father would hate to be tied down. He wouldn't even go to the dentist.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: That's how it's done. You have to keep the body going until the brain and heart recover enough to go on their own.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: He's better, though, right?

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: He's better.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Look, I'm sorry, but it's important to me. I mean, a week ago I was wishing he was dead. And now I want hear his voice again, just once more-- you know what I mean?

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: My father was a great man, you know. There was nobody he wouldn't help. You know that crazy guy Noel who I gave water to last night? He lived in our house for almost a year. A total stranger he'd do anything for, his own family though ...

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: It's best not to ...  It's good pizza, huh?

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Not as good as Nino's.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: You remember that pizza place, Joe's on Tenth Street maybe fifteen years ago?  When you ordered a pie it came with a little plastic madonna in the middle?

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Yeah, or Saint Anthony. You from the neighborhood?

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: I grew up on Elizabeth. I went to Blessed Sacrament.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: On yeah? I went to Holy Name. Where'd you go to high school?

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: We moved out after that. Upstate.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Like everybody else--except us. Always standing on the sidewalk waving goodbye to moving trucks. Your parents ... ?

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: They're fine. My old man was a bus driver, mom a nurse--I was sort of born to it, I guess.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: You married?

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Ah, no. I was.  It's hard to explain. She had a hard time adjusting to, well, maybe it was my fault too.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: It's been bad lately, but it's always bad.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: How long you been doing this?

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Five years.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Wow, you musta seen some things, huh? What's the worst thing you ever seen?

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: You learn to sort of block it out, you know, like cops fence off a crime scene. But then something good will happen and everything will just glow.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: You must get a lot of overdoses. I bet you picked me up a couple of times.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: I think I'd remember that.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Maybe not. I was a different person then. Does everybody you meet spill their problems on you like this?

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Mostly. It must be my face. My mother always said I looked like a priest.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: I better go check on my father. Thanks for the pizza. I owe you one. Maybe when he gets better, you know, when we're done with all this.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Sure.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Excuse me. You seemed like you were in trouble.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: I'm all right. I just can't stand to see people tied up.  I'm in the waiting room for hours, listening to Noel screaming. The only reason he's screaming is 'cause he's tied up.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Don't seem so bad to me.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Don't say that. I wanted to cut my father loose too. They told me he almost died and five minutes later they say he's better and I go in. It's killing me seeing him fighting like that.  Look, since you're here, maybe you could do me a favor. I need you to wait for me outside this building, okay? I have to visit a friend who's sick.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Okay.
